revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Francisco J. Ricardo | image = Francisco José Ricardo, Ph.D.jpg | alt = Francisco J. Ricardo with digital voice recorder in hand. | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = <!--Birthdate must be attributed to a reliable published source with an established reputation for fact-checking. No blogs. No IMDb. No public records. See WP:BLPPRIVACY--> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | nationality = Cuban, American | other_names = | occupation = Media philosopher, author, musician, filmmaker | known_for = Digital Video Research Archive, founder, ''International Texts in Critical Media Aesthetics'', director, ''F For Franco'' }}
'''Francisco José Ricardo, Ph.D''' is a media philosopher, author, musician, theorist, and filmmaker. Ricardo is co-founder of the Digital Video Research Archive at [[Boston University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bu.edu/dbin/dance/|title=Morris, Sword, and Clog Dancing|publisher=}}</ref> and is also the founding editor of the book series, ''International Texts in Critical Media Aesthetics''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomsbury.com/us/series/international-texts-in-critical-media-aesthetics/?pg=1|title=Bloomsbury - International Texts in Critical Media Aesthetics|first=|last=Bloomsbury.com|publisher=}}</ref> published by Bloomsbury. This series focuses primarily on electronic, or [[digital art]], and will publish its twelfth book in 2017. In 2013, Ricardo published ''The Engagement Aesthetic: Experiencing New Media Art through Critique'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomsbury.com/us/the-engagement-aesthetic-9781623560409/|title=The Engagement Aesthetic|first=|last=Bloomsbury.com|publisher=}}</ref> in which he discusses different methods of reflecting on, interacting with, and critiquing [[new media art]]. As media and culture commentator, he examines the loss of reflection in social communication occurring in what he calls hashtag culture, characterized by diminished language, instinctive reactions and responses, a tendency to seek approval from others, and an obsession with certainty -- difficulties that he considers can be addressed by embracing expression through the arts and other self-directed creative activity. Ricardo has appeared on numerous radio talk shows to discuss this issue.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://soundcloud.com/conceptualist/wtop-fjr-interview-2017september18|title=WTOP Washington, DC News Radio, On Air Interview with Veronica Robinson|}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://soundcloud.com/conceptualist/hashtag-culture-on-kogo-21sep2017|title=Francisco Ricardo speaks about Hashtag Culture on NewsRadio 600 KOGO with Ted Garcia and LaDona Harvey|}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://soundcloud.com/conceptualist/francisco-speaks-on-followers-social-media-and-hashtag-culture-on-sirius|title=Francisco speaks on Followers, social media, on SiriusXM Urban View, The Laura Coates Show}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://soundcloud.com/conceptualist/francisco-speaks-with-terry-gilberg-on-social-media-hashtagculture|title=Francisco Speaks on Social Media and Hashtag Culture with Terry Gilberg}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Francisco J. Ricardo was born in 1962 in [[Havana]], [[Cuba]]. When he was seven, the family moved to [[Madrid]], [[Spain]], and two years later, to [[New York City]]. His father, an architect, and professor at the [[University of Havana]], had studied under [[Josef Albers]] during Albers's residency in Havana. His mother had been a gymnast, and in the U.S. founded a "Health Bauhaus" based on alternative nutrition and numerous forms of exercise, yoga, and meditation. Ricardo studied at [[Harvard University]], receiving a C.A.S [HGSE], and an Ed.M. Ricardo transferred during his doctoral work at Harvard to receive the first Ph.D. in Humanities Computing conferred in the U.S. at the pioneering [[University Professors Program]] of [[Boston University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cybertext.hum.jyu.fi/contributors.php|title=CyberText Yearbook|publisher=}}</ref> where he worked as Research Associate, later teaching art theory at the [[Rhode Island School of Design]].
==Career== After teaching at RISD, writing and presenting on artists and new media art, including electronic or [[digital art]] (see selected articles), Ricardo decided that he could better show this art, which often employs moving images, through the medium of film. He left teaching and formed the documentary film production company, Conceptualist Films.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://conceptualistfilms.com|title=ConceptualistFilms.com|publisher=}}</ref> Ricardo's vision is to create a new form of documentary on extraordinary artists and musicians - fewer "talking heads" and biographical material; instead, he wants to engage the viewer with unusual imagery while discussing ideas and philosophies in an experimental and accessible way.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://conceptualistfilms.com/press-release/|title=Press Release – Conceptualist Films Born!|date=22 June 2014|publisher=}}</ref>
The subject of his first documentary (released 2016) is on the creative art process of the multifaceted artist [[James Franco]]. Franco, once a student of Ricardo's at RISD, has a wide body of his own experimental art and film work which Ricardo explores in the film, according to the website for ''F FOR FRANCO.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fforfranco.com/|title=fforfranco|publisher=}}</ref> The film contains hours of conversations between Ricardo and Franco, in various places such as the [[LA Theater]] and The [[Chateau Marmont]], as well as footage given by Franco to Ricardo of work rarely, if ever, seen before.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://conceptualistfilms.com/on-the-subject-of-subjects-james-franco/|title=On the Subject of Subjects – James Franco|date=7 July 2014|publisher=}}</ref> The film had its world premiere at the Hollywood Film Festival in 2015, reviewed by Neon Tommy<ref>{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/neon-tommy/film-review-f-for-franco-ac92640b0fa6</ref> and was reviewed by ''The Hollywood Reporter'', stating it was a "must for Franco completists."<ref>[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/f-franco-film-review-748389 ]</ref>
==CD release== In 2014, Ricardo released an album of electronic music titled, ''Adding and Subtracting''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MUFM39E?ie=UTF8&keywords=adding%20and%20subtracting%20francisco&qid=1452585514&ref_=sr_1_1&sr=8-1|title=Adding and Subtracting|publisher=|via=Amazon}}</ref> His second album of electronic music,''Groove Morphisms''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0193MZFMI?ie=UTF8&keywords=groove%20morphisms&qid=1452584601&ref_=sr_1_1&sr=8-1|title=Groove Morphisms|publisher=|via=Amazon}}</ref> is more complex, and was released in December 2015. In early 2016, Francisco released ''A Singular Within'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01B73SLZE?ie=UTF8&keywords=a%20singular%20within&qid=1457418260&ref_=sr_1_1&sr=8-1|title=A Singular Within|publisher=|via=Amazon}}</ref> a collection of nine meditative, ambient songs reminiscent of the work of Brian Eno. It's a marked departure from his previous two albums. The digital version of ''A Singular Within'' contains two bonus tracks not found on the physical CD. Francisco composes his albums electronically, employing a variety of instruments, blending styles and creating complex rhythms. The latest are: *Minimal Souvenirs<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Minimal-Souvenirs-Francisco/dp/B01HGBW8BY/ref=sr_1_1?s=dmusic&ie=UTF8&qid=1506113581&sr=1-1-mp3-albums-bar-strip-0&keywords=Minimal+Souvenirs|title=Minimal Souvenirs}}</ref>, *Calligraphies<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Calligraphies-Francisco/dp/B01N8ORG97/ref=sr_1_2?s=dmusic&ie=UTF8&qid=1506113613&sr=1-2-mp3-albums-bar-strip-0&keywords=calligraphies|title=Calligraphies}}</ref>, *F For Franco (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Franco-Original-Motion-Picture-Soundtrack/dp/B01LF4EG9K/ref=sr_1_1?s=dmusic&ie=UTF8&qid=1506113657&sr=1-1-mp3-albums-bar-strip-0&keywords=F+for+franco|title=F For Franco Original Motion Picture Soundtrack}}</ref>, *PhilsPhases<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Philsphases-Francisco/dp/B01NCNHQZX/ref=sr_1_1?s=dmusic&ie=UTF8&qid=1506113697&sr=1-1-mp3-albums-bar-strip-0&keywords=philsphases|title=PhilsPhases}}</ref>, *Meridians<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Meridians-Francisco/dp/B077W4F5B2/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1526504345&sr=8-2&keywords=meridians+francisco}}</ref> and *Sound Seance<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Sound-Seance-Francisco/dp/B06Y1BWXG6/ref=sr_1_1?s=dmusic&ie=UTF8&qid=1506113728&sr=1-1-mp3-albums-bar-strip-0&keywords=sound+seance|title=Sound Seance}}</ref>
==Other books== *''Cyberculture and New Media'' (Ed.)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Cyberculture-Media-Interface-Probing-Boundaries/dp/9042025182|title=Cyberculture and New Media.|editor-first=Francisco J.|editor-last=Ricardo|date=22 December 2008|publisher=Rodopi|via=Amazon}}</ref> *''Literary Art in Digital Performance: Case Studies in New Media Art and Criticism'' (Ed.)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Literary-Art-Digital-Performance-Criticism/dp/0826436803|title=Literary Art in Digital Performance: Case Studies in New Media Art and Criticism|editor-first=Francisco J.|editor-last=Ricardo|date=26 November 2009|publisher=Bloomsbury Academic|via=Amazon}}</ref>
==Bibliography== ;Books in the series ''International Texts in Critical Media Aesthetics'' * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/new-directions-in-digital-poetry-9781441115911/ ''New Directions in Digital Poetry'' - CT Funkhouser (01-2012) ''Continuum''] * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/cybertext-poetics-9781441107459/ ''Cybertext Poetics - The Critical Landscape of New Media Theory'' - Markku Eskelinen (03-2012) ''Continuum''] * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/creative-enterprise-9781441188205/ ''Creative Enterprise - Contemporary Art between Museum and Marketplace'' - Martha Buskirk (04-2012) ''Continuum''] * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/the-engagement-aesthetic-9781623560409/ ''The Engagement Aesthetic - Experiencing New Media Art Through Critique'' - Francisco J. Ricardo (05-2013) ''Bloomsbury Academic''] * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/software-takes-command-9781623567453/ ''Software Takes Command'' - Lev Manovich (07-2013) ''Bloomsbury Academic''] * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/3d-9781441167262/ ''3D - History, Theory, and Aesthetics of the Transplane Image'' - Jens Schröter (01-2014) ''Bloomsbury Academic''] * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/when-the-machine-made-art-9781623568849/ ''When the Machine Made Art - The Troubled History of Computer Art'' - Grant D. Taylor (04-2014) ''Bloomsbury Academic''] * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/projected-art-history-9781623560324/ ''Projected Art History - Biopics, Celebrity Culture, and the Popularizing of American Art'' - Doris Berger (05-2014) ''Bloomsbury Academic''] * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/the-internet-unconscious-9781628923384/ '' The Internet Unconscious - On the Subject of Electronic Literature'' - Sandy Baldwin (02-2015) ''Bloomsbury Academic''] * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/between-film-video-and-the-digital-9781628922936/ '' Between Film, Video, and the Digital - Hybrid Moving Images in the Post-Media Age'' - Jihoon Kim (07-2016) ''Bloomsbury Academic''] * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/the-off-modern-9781501328978/ ''The Off-Modern'' - Svetlana Boym (06-2017) ''Bloomsbury Academic''] * [https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/witness-to-phenomenon-9781501331176/ '' Witness to Phenomenon - Group ZERO and the Development of New Media in Postwar European Art'' - Joseph D. Ketner II (12-2017) ''Bloomsbury Academic'']
==Articles on critical and computational knowledge management== *[http://cmc.uib.no/dac98/papers/ricardo.html "Field Notes From The Secret War Between Value and Meaning in Digital Culture," Digital Arts and Culture, Bergen Norway, November 26, 1998.] *[https://archive.is/20140521061114/http://cds.library.brown.edu/conferences/DAC/abstracts/ricardo.html "Aspects of Knowledge Representation in Digital Culture," Fourth Annual Digital Arts and Culture Conference, Providence, Rhode Island, April 26-28, 2001.] *[http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.42.1218&rep=rep1&type=pdf "Stalking the Paratext: Speculations on Hypertext Links as a Second Order Text," HYPERTEXT '98 Proceedings of the Ninth ACM conference on Hypertext and Hypermedia, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, June 20-24, 1998.] *[http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=504269 "Hypertext and Knowledge Management," HYPERTEXT '01 Proceedings of the 12th ACM conference on Hypertext and Hypermedia, Århus, Denmark, August 14-18, 2001.]

Ricardo (2009) ''Continuum''] *[https://www.facebook.com/conceptfilms Conceptualist Films Facebook Page] *[http://conceptualistfilms.com/ official website]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{About|the Roy Lichtenstein painting|the sporting good|golf ball}} {{Good article}} {{Infobox artwork | title = Golf Ball | image = Golf Ball.jpg | image_size = 200px | artist = [[Roy Lichtenstein]] | year = {{start date|1962}} | movement = [[Pop art]] | height_metric = 81.3 | width_metric = 81.3 | metric_unit = cm | museum = Private collection }}
'''''Golf Ball''''' (sometimes '''''Golfball''''') is a 1962 painting by [[Roy Lichtenstein]]. It is considered to fall within the [[art movement]] known as [[Pop art]]. It depicts "a single sphere with patterned, variously directional semi-circular grooves."<ref>{{cite book|title=Pop Art|last=Lippard|first=Lucy R.|publisher=[[Praeger Publishers]]|year=1970|edition=third printing|isbn=|page=125|chapter=New York Pop}}</ref> The work is commonly associated with black-and-white [[Piet Mondrian]] works. It is one of the works that was presented at Lichtenstein's first solo exhibition and one that was critical to his early association with pop art. The work is commonly critiqued for its tension involving a three-dimensional representation in two dimensions with much discussion revolving around the choice of a background nearly without any perspective.
==History== When Lichtenstein had his first solo show at the [[Leo Castelli Gallery]] in February 1962, it sold out before opening.<ref>{{cite book|title=Roy Lichtenstein: Mural With Blue Brushstroke|last=Tomkins|first=Calvin|publisher=[[Harry N. Abrams, Inc.]]|year=1988|isbn=0-8109-2356-4|location=|page=25|pages=|quote=His first show at Castelli's, in February 1962, was sold out before the opening.}}</ref> ''Golf Ball'' was one of the works that Lichtenstein exhibited.<ref>{{cite book|title=Pop Art: A Critical History|last=|first=|publisher=[[University of California Press]]|year=1997|isbn=0-520-21018-2|editor-last=Madoff|editor-first=Steven Henry|location=|page=198|pages=|chapter=Focus: The Major Artists|quote=Yes. The first show was very diverse.}}</ref> Later, Lichtenstein included ''Golf Ball'' in ''Still Life with Goldfish Bowl'', 1972, and ''Go for Baroque'', 1979.<ref>{{harvnb|Waldman|1993|loc=''Still Lifes: 1972–76'', pp. 206–7, 216–7|quote=}}</ref> The painting exemplifies the novel [[superimposition]] of abstraction and [[Figurative art|figuration]].<ref name="RLMOA60">{{cite book|title=Roy Lichtenstein: Meditations 0n Art|author=Mercurio, Gianni|first=|publisher=SKIRA|year=2010|isbn=978-88-572-0460-4|location=|page=60|pages=|quote=Good examples of just how abstraction and figuration were superimposed to propose fresh solutions are Lichtenstein's ''Golf Ball'' (1962) and ''Ball of Twine'' (1963).}}</ref> The work also represents abstraction as a result of elimination of three-dimensionality, [[chiaroscuro]] and a landscape context.<ref name=RLMOA61>{{cite book|title=Roy Lichtenstein: Meditations 0n Art|author=Mercurio, Gianni|publisher=SKIRA|isbn=978-88-572-0460-4|year=2010|page=61|quote=''Golf Ball'' and ''Ball of Twine'' highlight how the more an image is synthesized by eliminating its three-dimensionality, chiaroscuro and a landscape context, the more it takes on the characteristics of abstraction.)}}</ref>
[[File:Composition in Black and White, 1917.jpg|thumb|upright|left|''Golf Ball'' is said to reflect the black and white elements of ''Compositions in Black and White'', 1917, [[Piet Mondrian]].]] The use of black and white is regarded as dramatic, and although it may have been influenced by 1940s and 1950s works of [[Willem de Kooning]], [[Franz Kline]] and [[Robert Motherwell]], it is more likely a commentary on Mondrian's 1917 ''Composition in Black and White''.<ref name=W33/> Alternatively, it may have been a reference to another of Mondrian's Pre-[[World War I]] black and white oval paintings, such as ''Pier and ocean'', 1915.<ref name="RLJH">{{harvnb|Hendrickson|1993|loc=''The Pictures That Lichtenstein made Famous, or The Pictures that Made Lichtenstein Famous'', pp. 25–26}} For someone familiar with modern art, the formally related oval paintings of Piet Mondrian from before the First World War (Ill. p. 26) may come to mind.</ref> This complementary source art was common of Lichtenstein's 1960s work on frequently advertised objects.<ref name="W33">{{harvnb|Waldman|1993|loc=''Cliches into Icons: Early Pop Pictures'', p. 29-31}} "Lichtenstein's dramatic use of black and white is also a feature of subsequent paintings such as ''Golf Ball'', 1962 ...</ref> Lichtenstein describes his sources as Mondrian ''Plus and Minus'' paintings.<ref name=RLOF/>
==Description== [[File:Roy Lichtenstein.jpg|thumb|upright|Lichtenstein in 1967]] In 1962, Lichtenstein produced several works in which he depicted "...the repetitive regularity of their patterned surfaces..."<ref>{{harvnb|Hendrickson1993|loc=''The Pictures That Lichtenstein made Famous, or The Pictures that Made Lichtenstein Famous'', p. 46}}</ref> ''Golf Ball'' is a depiction of a [[golf ball]] using a [[Piet Mondrian|Mondrian]]esque set of black and white arcs to depict the three-dimensionality of the subject. However, the neutral background manipulates the image and diminishes the volumetric characteristics by stripping the viewer of his perspective.<ref>{{cite book|page=15|title=Roy Lichtenstein|last=Waldman|first= Diane|publisher=The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation|year=1969|quote=''Golf Ball'', 1962 is composed of a series of black and white arcs that form an abstract pattern reminiscent of Mondrian’s plus and minus system. At the same time, by means of their placement, these black and white lines conform to the shape of a three-dimensional object. But the placement of the golf ball on a neutral ground once again neutralizes the object as a volumetric form. This manipulation of the two and three dimensional is one that the artist obviously relishes for he returns to it repeatedly.}}</ref> It is described as a "pure graphic mark on a gray ground" as well as a "totality of abstract marks."<ref name=RLMOA60/> Lichtenstein described ''Golf Ball'' as "the antithesis of what was thought of as having 'art meaning'" because of its lack of perspective.<ref name="RLOF">{{cite book|title=Roy Lichtenstein: October Files|author=Lichtenstein, Roy|first=|publisher=[[The MIT Press]]|year=2009|isbn=978-0-262-51231-2|editor-last=Bader|editor-first=Graham|location=|page=60|pages=|chapter=A Review of My Work Since 1961—A Slide Presentation|quote=''Golf Ball'' (1962), a painting of a single object, is intended to remind one of a Mondrian ''Plus and Minus'' painting.}}</ref>
''Golf Ball'' is an example of the emerging "confident authority" of his single-image paintings with its "Rock of Gibraltar-like thereness".<ref name=RLLA/> The "frontal and centralized presentation"'s directness lacked the sophistication to market the images of household goods for advertising but was considered daring artistically.<ref>{{cite book|title=Pop Art: A Continuing History|last=Livingstone|first=Marco|publisher=[[Harry N. Abrams]]|year=1990|isbn=0-8109-3707-7|location=|pages=|quote=The frontal and centralized presentation employed by Lichtenstein in early pairings of domestic objects, such as ''Roto Broil'' and ''Electric Cord'' of 1961 and ''Golf Ball'' (1962), was of such assertive directness that it would have been dismissed in contemporary advertising as too crude and unsophisticated. In the context of painting, however, this projection of an image so as to be instantly apprehended as a whole – as a perceptual pattern or structure that in psychological terms would be labelled a Gestalt – was daring in its austere simplicity, anticipating the Minimalism of the mid 1960s.}}</ref> The black and white painting on a grey background challenges both the natural perception of [[Realism (arts)|realism]] and the boundaries of abstraction.<ref name="P">{{cite book|title=Pop|last=Foster|first=Hal|publisher=[[Phaidon Press|Phaidon]]|year=2010|isbn=978-0-7148-5663-6|editor=Francis, Mark|location=|page=26|pages=|quote=A golf ball is a prime object of suburban banality, but here it also recalls the pristine plus-and-minus abstractions Mondrian painted forty-five years before.}}</ref> The work "gives us both the impression of space and the fact of surface".<ref>{{cite book|title=Pop|last=Foster|first= Hal|editor-last=Francis|editor-first= Mark|isbn=978-0-7148-5663-6|publisher=Phaidon|year=2010|page=27|quote=}}</ref>
''Golf Ball'' was one of the bases by which "critics aligned him with other practitioners of Pop Art", although much is made about the painting's references to abstract painting, especially its likeness to Mondrian's works. Furthermore, the painting leverages tensions regarding three-dimensional representation in two dimensions resulting from spatial ambiguities caused by the lack of cues in the background.<ref>{{cite book|title=Roy Lichtenstein: All About Art|last=Lobel|first=Michael|publisher=Louisiana Museum of Modern Art|year=2003|isbn=87-90029-85-2|editor1-last=Holm|editor1-first=Michael Juul|location=|page=84|pages=|chapter=Pop according To Lichtenstein|quote=...it was through paintings like...''Golf Ball''...that critics aligned him with other practitioners of Pop Art...Many of his paintings of objects veer toward abstraction, whether ''Golf Ball''{{'s}} radiating fields of arcs enclosed within a circular form...In this way these works often make reference to the traditions of abstract painting.|editor2-last=Tøjner|editor2-first=Poul Erik|editor3-last=Caiger-Smith|editor3-first=Martin}}</ref>
==Reception== Diane Waldman refers to the subject of ''Golf Ball'' as a freestanding form.<ref>{{cite book|title=Roy Lichtenstein: Reflections|last=Waldman |first=Diane|publisher=Electa|year=1999|isbn=88-435-7287-3|page=25|quote=}}</ref> This is one of the figures in which Lichtenstein demonstrates his draftsman experience.<ref>{{harvnb|Waldman|1993|loc=''Cliches into Icons: Early Pop Pictures'', p. 28}} "Lichtenstein's experience as a draftsman is reflected in his spare presentation of kitchen stoves, washing machines, bathroom interiors, golf balls, ice cream sodas....</ref> This work demonstrated his maturation as an artist with standardized contours that present uniformity and solidified inflections.<ref name="RLLA">{{cite book|title=Roy Lichtenstein|last=Alloway|first=Lawrence|publisher=[[Abbeville Press]]|year=1983|isbn=0-89659-331-2|location=|pages=18–19|quote=This is particularly evident in the single-image paintings, which take on a Rock of Gibraltar-like thereness, and in the paintings from war comics, which have a clarity and elaboration in advance of the comparatively constrained romance subjects.}}</ref> This is a strong example of presenting the tension of volumetric potential balanced against two-dimensional presentation.<ref>{{harvnb|Waldman|1993|loc=''Cliches into Icons: Early Pop Pictures'', p. 33}} "Both ''Black Flowers'' and ''Golf Ball'' are successful examples of this dialectic.</ref> It also shows how placement against a neutral background diminishes three-dimensionality.<ref>{{cite book|title=Pop Art: A Critical History|last=|first=|publisher=[[University of California Press]]|year=1997|isbn=0-520-21018-2|editor-last=Steven Henry|editor-first=Madoff|location=|page=208|pages=|chapter=Focus: The Major Artists|quote=At the same time, by means of their placement, the black and white lines conform to the shape of a three-dimensional object. But the placement of the golf ball on a neutral ground once again neutralizes the object as a volumetric form.}}</ref> Despite Lichtenstein's techniques to display/minimize dimensionality, the viewer imposes his or her own visualization experiences on the painting, which minimizes the effect of spatial illusion.<ref>{{harvnb|Waldman|1993|loc=''Comic Strips and Advertising Images'', p. 47}} "We know that a golf ball is three-dimensional, and so most of us project the additional dimension onto such a two-dimensional image even though it may not be depicted in that manner."</ref>
==See also== * [[1962 in art]]
==Notes== {{reflist|30em}}
==References== {{refbegin}} *{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/29232214|title=Roy Lichtenstein|last=Waldman|first= Diane|year=1993|publisher=[[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]]|isbn=0892071087|oclc=29232214|ref=harv}} *{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/37226637|title=Roy Lichtenstein|last=Hendrickson|first=Janis|date=1993|publisher=[[Benedikt Taschen]]|isbn=3822896330|oclc=37226637|ref=harv}} {{refend}}
==External links== *[http://image-duplicator.com/main.php?work_id=0077&year=1962&decade=60 ''Golf Ball''] at the Lichtenstein Foundation website
{{Roy Lichtenstein}}
[[Category:1962 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Roy Lichtenstein]] [[Category:Sports paintings]] [[Category:Still life paintings]]

{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[File:2007 06 19 Maria Kaczynska 01.jpg|thumb|[[Hansō Sōshitsu|Genshitsu Sen]], 15th ''iemoto'' of the ''[[Urasenke]]'' school]] {{Nihongo|'''''Iemoto'''''|家元|lead=yes|extra2=(lit. "family foundation")}} is a [[Japanese language|Japanese term]] used to refer to the founder or current Grand Master of a certain school of traditional Japanese art. It is used synonymously with the word {{nihongo||宗家|[[sōke]]}} when it refers to the family or house that the iemoto is head of and represents.
The word ''iemoto'' is also used to describe a system of familial generations in traditional Japanese arts such as [[Japanese tea ceremony|tea ceremony]] (inc. [[sencha tea ceremony]]), [[ikebana]], [[noh]], [[calligraphy]], [[traditional Japanese dance]], [[traditional Japanese music]], the Japanese art of incense appreciation ([[Japanese incense#Kōdō|kōdō]]), and [[Japanese martial arts]]. [[Shogi]] and [[Go (board game)|go]] once used the ''iemoto'' system as well. The ''iemoto'' system is characterized by a hierarchical structure and the supreme authority of the ''iemoto'', who has inherited the secret traditions of the school from the previous ''iemoto''. ==Titles== An ''iemoto'' may be addressed by the title ''Iemoto'' or ''O-iemoto'', or by the title {{nihongo||宗匠|Sōshō}} or {{nihongo||大先生|Ō-sensei}}. In English, "Grand Master" is often the title that is used. The ''iemoto's'' main roles are to lead the school and protect its traditions, to be the final authority on matters concerning the school, to issue or approve licenses and certificates and, in some cases, to instruct the most advanced practitioners.
The title of ''iemoto'' in most cases is hereditary. It is commonly transmitted by direct line, or by adoption. Once the "successor-to-be" is officially recognized, that successor-to-be may appropriate the title of {{nihongo||若宗匠|Wakasōshō|extra2="Young Master"}}.
There can only be one ''iemoto'' at a time, which sometimes leads to the creation of new "houses" or "lines."
By tradition, the title of ''iemoto'' is passed down along with a hereditary name. In the [[Urasenke]] tradition of tea ceremony, for example, the ''iemoto'' carries the name Sōshitsu. ==Structure== Officially recognized teachers of the traditional arts that have an "iemoto" have obtained a license to teach from the ''iemoto'', signifying the ''iemoto'''s trust that the so-licensed person is capable and qualified to faithfully pass on the school's teachings. Students must also acquire licenses or certificates at various stages in their study. Depending on the school, such certificates either give the student permission to study at a particular level or affirm that the student has achieved a given level of mastery. Recipients must pay for these certificates which, at the highest level, may cost several million [[Japanese yen|yen]]. It is also the ''iemoto'' who authorises, selects and bestows ceremonial names for advanced practitioners.
==History==
As far back as the [[Heian period]] (794-1185), there were iemoto-like family lines that were responsible for passing down the secret traditions and orthodox teachings of their particular school of art, but the first appearance of the word ''iemoto'' in extant records dates to the end of the 17th century, where it is used in reference to families entitled to have their sons become priests at great temples. Its use in the sense that it is used today, in the realm of traditional Japanese arts, starts to appear in documents in the middle of the 18th century.<ref>A Chanoyu Vocabulary: Practical Terms for the Way of Tea (Kyoto: Tankosha, 2007)</ref>
The system of iemoto is a manifestation of the {{nihongo||家|ie}} or "household" and {{nihongo||同族|dōzoku}} or "extended kin" pattern of relationships in Japanese society.<ref>"Iemoto" entry by Francis L. K. Hsu in Kodansha Encyclopedia of Japan</ref>
The concept of the {{Nihongo|"Iemoto System"|家元制度}} was explicated by the historian Matsunosuke Nishiyama in the post-war period to describe the social structures associated with exclusive family control and networks of instructors, a characteristic of the feudal era whose influence on traditional arts is still felt today.
==Famous families and schools== ===Go===
There were originally four main schools of [[Go_(game)|Go]] players: Hon'inbō, Hayashi, Inoue and Yasui; and three minor schools: Sakaguchi, Hattori and Mizutani.
Early in the 17th century, the then best player in Japan, [[Hon'inbō Sansa]], was made head of a newly founded Go academy (the {{Nihongo|[[Hon'inbō school]]|本因坊}}, which developed the level of playing greatly, and introduced the martial arts style system of ranking players. The government discontinued its support for the Go academies in 1868 as a result of the fall of the [[Tokugawa shogunate]].
In honour of the Hon'inbō school, whose players consistently dominated the other schools during their history, one of the most prestigious Japanese Go championships is called the "Honinbo" tournament.
===Ikebana===
The three main schools of Japanese flower arrangement, or [[ikebana]], are [[Ikenobō]], [[Ohara-ryū|Ohara]], and [[Sōgetsu]].
According to the organization Ikebana Network,<ref>http://www.kadou.com/hp/ryuuha.htm</ref> there currently are 138 registered schools of small and large size (as of August 2008).
===Japanese dancing===
There are about 200 schools of Japanese dancing. The five most famous are the Hanayagi-ryū, Fujima-ryū, Wakayagi-ryū, Nishikawa-ryū, and Bandō-ryū.
===Incense appreciation=== The two main schools of {{Nihongo|Incense appreciation|香道|kōdō}} are the Shino-ryū and the Nijō-ryū.
===Tea === see the article [[Schools of Japanese tea ceremony]]
==Criticisms and resistance==
The ''iemoto'' system has been described as rigid, expensive, nepotistic, authoritarian and undemocratic. Some groups have chosen to reject the ''iemoto'' system. In the realm of the Japanese tea ceremony, Sensho Tanaka in 1898 initiated the ''Dai Nihon Chado Gakkai''.<ref name="Dai Nihon Chado Gakkai">[http://www.santokuan.or.jp/eng/index.html] Dai Nihon Chado Gakkai official web site (English)</ref> Hiroaki Kikuoka, a [[shamisen]] player, created a presidential system for his group,<ref name=Metropolis>[http://metropolis.co.jp/biginjapanarchive299/266/biginjapaninc.htm "Hiroaki Kikuoka"], Metropolis</ref> while [[Koto (instrument)|koto]] player [[Michiyo Yagi]] has rejected both the ''iemoto'' system and the traditional style of her instrument, choosing to strike [[chord (music)|chords]].<ref name=Weekend>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1406597 "Japanese Classical Music"], Weekend Edition Sunday, August 24, 2003</ref>
==See also== *[[Dōshu]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ohararyu.or.jp/english/index_e.html Ohara ikebana school official site] *[http://www.sogetsu.or.jp/english/index.html Sōgetsu ikebana school official site] *[http://www.wakayagiryu-souke.jp Wakayagi-ryū Japanese classical dance iemoto's official site] *[https://sites.google.com/site/iemototheheartofjapan/ Iemoto: the heart of Japan]
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Chadō]] [[Category:Arts in Japan]] [[Category:Japanese words and phrases]] [[Category:Go (game)]]

revision.text:
'''Instant book''' is a term used in [[publishing]] to describe a [[book]] that has been produced and published very quickly to meet [[Demand|market demand]]. Normally when a book is published, it represents months of preparation and production—the [[Manufacturing|production]] process takes from two months to a year.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/15/business/on-the-endangered-list-the-instant-book.html|title=On the Endangered List: The 'Instant Book'|last=Freitag|first=Michael|date=1987-11-15|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-12-28}} An Instant book is one that is written and published very quickly to capitalize on a current news event or figure. Many of the scheduling and roadblocks in a publishing plan are put aside in order to get the book published as quickly as possible. Sometimes government documents or reports are published—they require little [[editing]] and are part of the [[public domain]]. The book generally has a very short lifespan once published—sales are expected to be high in the first few days and weeks and then drop off. == The early years == There are conflicting reports as to when the first instant book was published. There are reports that the first instant book appeared after the [[Chicago Fire of 1874|Chicago fire]] of 1874. There were Instant books published and sold door-to-door about the [[RMS Titanic|Titanic]] shortly after the disaster in 1912.{{Cite journal|last=White|first=Jay|year=1999|title=God's Ark: Subscription Book Publishing and the Titanic|url=http://jaywhite.ca/wp-content/uploads/titanic/documents/GodsArk.pdf|journal=Acadiensis|volume=XXVIII|pages=93–118|via=}} [[Pocket Books]] claims that they published the first instant book in 1945 after the death of President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] and the dropping of the [[Nuclear weapon|atomic bomb]] in [[Hiroshima]]. ==Twentieth century== It was in the latter half of the 20th century that American publishers used Instant books more commonly as part of their publishing plan. Instant books were published on the [[Northeast blackout of 1965]], the [[Moon landing]], the [[Iran hostage crisis]], and the murder of [[John Lennon]]. One of the most successful instant books was the [[Warren Commission|Warren Commission Report]] published in 1964 by [[Bantam Books]], which by 1987 had over 1.7 million copies in print. Bantam followed this book up with over 70 other instant books over the next couple of decades. Two ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' journalists wrote a book on the [[Jonestown massacre]] in 11 days, publishing it three hours before a competing work. [[Operation Entebbe]] and IBM's introduction of its [[PCjr]] home computer also received instant books.{{Cite news |title=160-page 'Instant Book' on IBM's PCjr Home Computer Due Out Today |last=Rosenberg |first=Ronald |date=1983-11-25 |work=The Boston Globe }} Instant books have gone in and out of favor over the years. By the late 1980s, [[the New York Times]] said that their high cost of production along with several failed Instant books caused publishers to back away from this process. Publishers printed instant books in mass paperback in high quantity print runs that resulted in returns to the publisher after public interest waned in the topic. But by the 1990s advances in the publishing and distribution had allowed costs to go down and some publishers built instant publishing back into their plans.{{Cite news|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20040209/21444-personnel-moves-at-running-press.html|title=Personnel Moves at Running Press|last=|first=|date=|work=|newspaper=PublishersWeekly.com|quote=As for the instant books, DeVito said that he'd like publishing to feel a little more urgency. "I definitely think that publishing has the ability to keep up with the electronic media. People force through an instant book now and then, but more often than not, the editorial and production staff try to keep people from doing that. We're at a stage now, with technology and smart management, where we can get out there very fast.|access-date=2016-12-28|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Gross|first=Jerry|date=July 1997|title=St Martin's Press's Charles Spicer: 'Instant books must truly be worth it.'|url=|journal=Writer's Digest|volume=|pages=33|via=GALE Biography in Context}} St Martin's Press published several instant books in the late 1990s focusing on true-crime, including books on the [[O. J. Simpson murder trial|O.J. Simpson case]] (''Fallen Hero'') and the [[Susan Smith]] case (''Sins of the Mother''). Executive editor, Charles Spicer, described to ''[[Writer's Digest]]'' how he looked for authors who were experienced reporters who were capable of gathering information quickly and writing to a deadline. He had chosen [[Carleton Smith|Carlton Smith]], an experienced reporter, to write an instant book on the [[Death of JonBenét Ramsey|Jon Benet Ramsay]] case (''Death of a Little Princess''). Spicer said that a book needed to be able to sell hundreds of thousands of copies to be worth a publisher's effort for an instant book. ==21st century== Some types of instant books did not fare well in the 21st century. The advent of the [[Internet]] affected government and document instant publishing—a government document or report could be posted online instead of printed in book form for easy public access. Instead of publishing documents—publishers looked for other ways to create value with instant books by focusing on major sporting and news events.{{Cite news|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20020325/26992-a-seabiscuit-stampede.html|title=A 'Seabiscuit' Stampede|newspaper=PublishersWeekly.com|access-date=2016-12-28}} Often a book publisher will team up with newspapers. [[Triumph Books]], a division of Random House, is an example of a publisher that focuses on creating instant books with newspapers. Triumph worked with [[Los Angeles Times]] to publish a book commemorating the 2012 [[Stanley Cup]], and with the [[Chicago Tribune]] for an Instant book commemorating the [[2016 World Series|2016 World series]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/52582-triumph-scores-with-stanley-cup-instant-book.html|title=Triumph Scores With Stanley Cup Instant Book|last=|first=|date=|work=|newspaper=PublishersWeekly.com|quote=The book, which was produced with a 10,000-copy print run, documents in text and illustrations provided by the Los Angeles Times the number eight playoff seed’s unlikely journey towards the first Stanley Cup championship.|access-date=2016-12-28|via=}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/72088-this-week-s-bestsellers-november-21-2016.html|title=This Week's Bestsellers: November 21, 2016|newspaper=PublishersWeekly.com|access-date=2016-12-28}} JHU Press is an example of a publisher producing an Instant book tied to a news event. JHU Press published an instant book on the Gun Violence debate shortly after the Sandy Hook incident with materials gathered from a summit that was quickly conceived and put together. The publisher Press described their process for publishing an instant book using a simultaneous process to Publisher's Weekly in 2013:
Kathy Alexander, JHU Press’ publicity manager, reports that while the press is more accustomed to a publishing process that typically takes 11 months from transmission of the manuscript to book release, they are able to produce ''Reducing Gun Violence'' in 14 days by shifting from a linear production process, in which every task occurs in order, to a more simultaneous process, in which different tasks are performed at the same time.
The cover, for example, was designed before the title was finalized,” Anderson explained, “Metadata was pushed out to booksellers before the manuscript was complete. Even the peer review process was changed to accommodate the schedule with multiple readers reviewing individual parts simultaneously.”{{Cite news|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/55528-johns-hopkins-press-publishes-first-instant-book.html|title=JHU Press Publishes First Instant Book In Response to Gun Violence|newspaper=PublishersWeekly.com|access-date=2016-12-28}}
Over the years, printers and book manufacturers have adjusted their process to accommodate instant books through innovation and updating printing practices.{{Cite news|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20021028/21532-book-production-shifts-gears.html|title=Book Production Shifts Gears|last=|first=|date=|work=|newspaper=PublishersWeekly.com|quote=All over the industry, printing records are being broken. At Inland Press in Menomenee Falls, Wis., president Jim Lacy said the company prides itself on an under-15-day turnaround from receipt of purchase order to books shipped out. In the next few years, Lacy says, he is determined to get it down to 10 days. Ironically, the aspect of book publication that hasn't speeded up considerably is the sales and marketing cycle. On a normal schedule, the sales people still need to present a book to the marketplace five to six months before the on-sale date. On an exceptional basis, with an instant book, everything goes much faster.|access-date=2016-12-28|via=}} Where once a large print run was needed for an instant book (but often translated in high returns), now smaller print runs can make instant publishing more feasible. == Notable instant books == * The [[Warren Commission Report]] published by Bantam Books with the New York Times. *''Taking the Stand: The Testimony of Lieutenant Colonel Oliver L. North'' * ''Titanic'' instant books{{Cite web|url=http://jaywhite.ca/wp-content/uploads/titanic/titanic.htm|title=|website=jaywhite.ca|access-date=2016-12-30}} * The [[Tower Commission]] Report == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{Books}} [[Category:Book terminology]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/104.48.80.76|104.48.80.76]] ([[User talk:104.48.80.76|talk]]) to last version by PulauKakatua19
revision.text:
{{Infobox Korean name |img=Seoul_Gyeongbokgung_Throne.jpg |caption=Irworobongdo at the throne hall of [[Gyeongbokgung Palace]] |hangul=일월오봉도 / 일월도 / 일월곤륜도 |hanja={{linktext|日|月|五|峯|圖}} / {{linktext|日|月|圖}} / {{linktext|日|月|崑|崙|圖}} |rr=Irworobongdo / Irwoldo / Irwolgonnyundo |mr=Irwŏrobongdo / Irwŏlto / Irwŏlgonnyundo }}
'''Irworobongdo''' is a [[Korea]]n [[folding screen]] with a highly stylized [[landscape painting]] of a [[sun]] and [[moon]], five peaks which always was set behind [[Phoenix Throne|''Eojwa'']], the king’s royal [[throne]] during the [[Joseon Dynasty]].<ref name="KTO">{{cite web|url=http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_6.jsp?cid=259914 |title=The National Palace Museum of Korea |publisher=[[Korea Tourism Organization]] |accessdate=2008-11-20}}</ref><ref name="NYT">{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE5D61038F936A25753C1A965958260 |title=Sampling of Treasures From 18th-Century Korea |author=Holland Cotter |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=October 15, 1993}}</ref> It literally means ''"Painting of the Sun, Moon and the Five Peaks"'' and is also called "Irwoldo" or "Irwolgonryundo". The sun and moon symbolize the king and queen while the five peaks denotes a mythical place. The screen serves to display the majesty of the [[Joseon Dynasty|Joseon]] royal court.<ref name="EncyKorea">{{cite web|url=http://100.empas.com/dicsearch/pentry.html?s=K&i=257096&v=43 |script-title=ko:일월곤륜도 (日月崑崙圖)|publisher=[[Empas]] / [[EncyKorea]] |language=Korean |accessdate=2008-11-17}}</ref>
==Description of the image== The scene depicts a burning red sun, a full moon, five craggy peaks, and two fast-flowing streams with [[Waterfall|cascades]], all flanked by a pair of conifers. The brilliant colours — known as tang-chae (Chinese colours) — were fixed with either animal or fish glue, rendering the screens brilliant and waterfast.<ref name="HKMJ 1998">{{cite journal|url=http://sunzi1.lib.hku.hk/hkjo/view/22/2200381.pdf |title=Sun, moon, and five peaks |author=Chadwick A. |journal=Hong Kong Medical Journal |date=June 1998 |volume= 4 |issue=2 |pages=114–115}}</ref> [[New York Times]] critic Holland Cotter has described the screen's solid, saturated colors and robust forms as being regular as "textile patterns", and noted that these screens have "an archaic, hieratic look unlike Chinese or Japanese painting of the time." <ref name="NYT" />
==Symbolic significance== [[Image:Gojong-King.of.the.Korean.Empire-1903.jpg|thumb|left|The Irworobongdo on a portrait of Gojong, king of Joseon Dynasty]] There are no existing documents from an early period to explain the original [[iconography]] of the Five Peaks. Chadwick reports the findings of Dr. Yi Song-mi, Professor of Art History at the [[Academy of Korean Studies]] in [[Seoul]].<ref name="Yi Seong-mi">Yi Seong-mi, The screen of the Five Peaks of the Choson dynasty. Oriental Art 1996/1997;XLII/4:13–23.</ref> He has suggested that these screens were one of the most important elements in the throne hall, and that this formalized landscape illustrates the [[Joseon Dynasty|Joseon]] political [[cosmology]].<ref name="HKMJ">{{cite journal|url=http://sunzi1.lib.hku.hk/hkjo/view/22/2200175.pdf |title=Sun, moon, and Immortal Peaches |author=Chadwick A. |journal=Hong Kong Medical Journal |date=September 1996 |volume=2 |issue=3 |pages=234–235}}</ref> The "almost" red sun represents the king as the yang, the positive male principle, while the white moon represents the queen as the yin, the negative female principle. These two principles make the universe work.
An alternative explanation is that the screen might represent the blessing of Korea by Heaven, symbolized by the sun and moon in balance. When the king sat in front of this screen, he appeared to be at the pivotal point from which all force emanated and to which all returned. Thus, imbued with sacred power, the screen manifests a political cosmology as evidence of Heaven's favour, mandate, and continued protection of the ruler.<ref name="HKMJ 1998"/>
==History of the screens== Chadwick (1998)<ref name="HKMJ 1998"/> also reports Yi's (1996)<ref name="Yi Seong-mi" /> study of the history of such screens. He attempts to establish whether they were used at the start of the [[Joseon Dynasty]] reigned by [[Taejo of Joseon|King Taejo]] (r. 1392–1398). One suggestion Yi reports is that the practice of using the Five Peaks screen was established by [[Jeong Do-jeon]]. He was instrumental in the adoption of [[Neo-Confucianism]] as the Joseon's state [[ideology]]. Jeong Do-jeon used the screen as an important part of the design of the Joseon palace architecture in 1392. However, there is a painting from the 16th century referred to as "The martial arts performance at Soch'ong-dae in the reign of [[Myeongjong of Joseon|King Myeongjong]]" (r. 1545–1567) and there is no screen behind the throne. A 19th century copy however has the screen in place behind the throne. Yi therefore suggests that the 1392 date might be far too early and prefers a more recent date for the establishment of the screens. He suggests that screens role might well have been adopted after the 1592 [[Japanese invasions of Korea (1592–1598)|Imjin wars]] as an attempt to reaffirm the dynasty's power. [[Image:Sungmundang (interior 2), Changgyeonggung - Seoul, Korea.jpg|thumb|Right|The Irworobongdo at Changgyeonggung]]
The [[National Museum of Korea]]'s entry on the screens asserts that the earliest written evidence for the use of a Sun, Moon, and Five Peaks screen in the Joseon palace dates from the mid-seventeenth century, but suggests that they could have been used earlier, as part of the Joseon court tried to distinguish itself from that of the [[Goryeo]] court.<ref>[http://www.emuseum.go.kr/eng/mus/nat_10.jsp The National Museum of Korea] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120216035810/http://www.emuseum.go.kr/eng/mus/nat_10.jsp |date=2012-02-16 }}</ref>
Palace records suggest that the screens were constantly being produced. Today however, only around twenty originals remain. None are signed. Examples of the screens can be seen at royal palaces in [[Seoul]] such as at [[Gyeongbokgung|Gyeongbok Palace]], [[Changdeokgung|Changdeok Palace]] and [[Changgyeonggung]].<ref name="EncyKorea" />
==See also== *[[List of Korea-related topics]] *[[Korean art]] *[[Five Mountains of Korea]]
== References == {{Reflist}} {{Commons category}}
== Other sources == * Kim H. N. Exploring eighteenth century courts arts. In: Korean arts of the eighteenth century: splendor and simplicity. New York: Asia Society Galleries, 1993:40–1.
[[Category:Korean painting]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox writer | image = Janet Evanovich 20100914.jpg | name = Janet Evanovich | caption = | pseudonym = Steffie Hall,
Janet Evanovich | birth_name = Janet Schneider | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1943|4|22|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[South River, New Jersey]], U.S. | occupation = Novelist | nationality = American | alma_mater = [[Rutgers University]] | period = 1987–present | genre = [[Romance novel|Romance]], suspense, [[mystery fiction|mystery]] | movement = | notableworks = Stephanie Plum series | influences = | influenced = | spouse = Pete Evanovich (1964–present) | children = Peter, Alexandra | website = {{URL|http://www.evanovich.com}} }} '''Janet Evanovich''' (born '''Janet Schneider'''; April 22, 1943) is an American writer. She began her career writing short contemporary [[romance novels]] under the pen name '''Steffie Hall''', but gained fame authoring a series of contemporary mysteries featuring [[Stephanie Plum]], a former lingerie buyer from [[Trenton, New Jersey]], who becomes a [[bounty hunter]] to make ends meet after losing her job. The novels in this series have been on ''The New York Times'', [[USA Today]], ''[[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]]'' and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] bestseller lists. Evanovich has had her last seventeen Plums debut at #1 on the ''NY Times'' Best Sellers list and eleven of them have hit #1 on ''USA Today'' Best-Selling Books list. She has over two hundred million books in print worldwide and is translated into over 40 languages. == Early years == Evanovich is a second-generation American born in [[South River, New Jersey]] to a [[machinist]] and a housewife. After attending [[South River High School (New Jersey)|South River High School]],Nussbaum, Debra. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9802E3DA113FF930A35752C1A9649C8B63 "IN PERSON; Imagine Trenton. One Author Did."], ''The New York Times'', November 3, 2002. Accessed March 20, 2011. "She graduated from South River High School, married her high school sweetheart and attended Douglass College.... If there is a typical career path for novelists, Mrs. Evanovich is certain that she has not followed it. After growing up in South River, she followed her husband, who was in the Navy, as he moved around the country, stayed at home and raised their two children and then, when she was in her 30s, decided that she wanted to write." she became the first in her family to attend college when she enrolled at [[Douglass College]], part of [[Rutgers University]], to study art.{{cite web|last=MacDonald|first=Jay|title=Fame and Fortune: Author Janet Evanovich|publisher=Bankrate.com|date=October 24, 2006|accessdate=2007-08-14|url=http://www.bankrate.com/cbsmw/news/investing/Oct06_fame_fortune_Janet_Evanovich_a3.asp}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} When Evanovich had children, she chose to become a housewife like her mother. In her thirties, she began writing novels. To learn the art of writing dialog, Evanovich took lessons in [[Improvisational theatre|improv acting]]. For ten years, she attempted to write the [[Great American Novel]], finishing three manuscripts that she was unable to sell. After someone suggested she try writing [[romance novels]], Evanovich read several romances and discovered that she enjoyed the genre. She wrote two romances and submitted them for publishing.{{cite web|last=Jean|first=Lorna|publisher=All About Romance|title=Quickie with Janet Evanovich on her Stephanie Plum Series|date=September 18, 1998|url=http://www.likesbooks.com/quick20.html|accessdate=2007-08-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070906013522/http://www.likesbooks.com/quick20.html|archivedate=September 6, 2007|df=mdy-all}} Still unable to find a publisher, Evanovich stopped writing and signed with a temporary employment agency. Several months after beginning work for them, she received an offer to buy her second romance manuscript for $2,000, which she considered an "astounding sum."{{cite web|last=White|first=Claire E.|title=A Conversation with Janet Evanovich|publisher=The Internet Writing Journal|accessdate=2007-08-13|url=http://www.writerswrite.com/journal/jan99/evanovch.htm|date=January 1999}} ==Romance novels== That novel, ''Hero at Large'', was published in 1987 in the Second Chance Love category line under the pseudonym Steffie Hall. The following year she began writing for Bantam Loveswept under her own name. For the next five years she continued to write category romances for Loveswept. Her work within the romance novel genre helped her learn to create likable characters and attractive leading men. In this time, Evanovich also became known for the humor that filled her novels. She believes that "it's very important to take a comic approach. If we can laugh at something, we can face it." After finishing her twelfth romance, however, Evanovich realized that she was more interested in writing the action sequences in her novels than the sex scenes. Her editors were not interested in her change of heart, so Evanovich took the next eighteen months to formulate a plan for what she actually wanted to write.{{Cite news|last=Cochran |first=Tracy |title=Jersey Janet Takes on the World |newspaper=[[Publishers Weekly]] |date=June 30, 2003 |accessdate=2007-08-13 |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA308240.html?display=current&industry=Features&verticalid=792&q=romance+writers+of+america |postscript= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203145352/http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA308240.html?display=current&industry=Features&verticalid=792&q=romance%2Bwriters%2Bof%2Bamerica |archivedate=February 3, 2009 |df= }} ===Stephanie Plum Series=== She quickly decided that she wanted to write romantic adventure novels. Unlike the style of romance novels, her books would be told in [[first person narrative]]. Her new type of writing should contain heroes and heroines, as well as "a sense of family and community." In that vein, she intended her new style of writing to be based on the TV sitcom model. Like [[Seinfeld]], her new books would have a central character that the rest of the cast of characters revolve around.{{cite web|last=Tierney|first=Bruce|title=Janet Evanovich: Mystery maven keeps readers coming back for more|publisher=BookPage|date=July 2000|accessdate=2007-08-14|url=http://www.bookpage.com/0007bp/janet_evanovich.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703015540/http://www.bookpage.com/0007bp/janet_evanovich.html|archivedate=July 3, 2007|df=mdy-all}} Inspired by the [[Robert De Niro]] movie ''[[Midnight Run]]'', Evanovich decided that her heroine would be a [[bounty hunter]]. This occupation provided more freedom for Evanovich as a writer, as bounty hunters do not have a set work schedule and are not forced to wear a uniform. The profession is also "romanticised to some extent."{{Cite news|last=Jakeman |first=Jane |title=The Books Interview:Janet Evanovich – Plum jobs for a woman of parts |newspaper=The (London) Independent |date=October 21, 2000 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20001021/ai_n14357679 |accessdate=2007-08-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080211192718/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20001021/ai_n14357679 |archivedate=February 11, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} To become acquainted with the demands of the career, Evanovich spent a great deal of time shadowing bond enforcement agents. She also researched more about the city of [[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton]], where she wanted her books to be set. In 1994, her initial romantic adventure, ''[[One for the Money (novel)|One for the Money]]'', was published to good reviews. This was the first of a light-hearted series of mysteries starring barely competent bounty hunter [[Stephanie Plum]]. ''One for the Money'' was named a ''New York Times'' notable book, a ''Publishers Weekly'' Best Book of 1994 and a ''USA Today'' Best Bet.{{Cite web|last=Hayward|first=Mike|title=Interview: Janet Evanovich discusses Twelve Sharp and much else, with Mike Hayward |publisher=BookBrowse|url=http://www.bookbrowse.com/author_interviews/full/index.cfm?author_number=232|year=2006|accessdate=2007-08-14}} Evanovich has continued to write romantic adventures starring Stephanie Plum. The sixth book in the series, ''Hot Six'', was the first of her novels to reach number one on the [[New York Times Best Seller List]]. Her subsequent Plum novels have each debuted at number one.{{Cite news|last=Cruz|first=Gilbert|title=How Janet Evanovich broke through|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=June 2, 2006|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1199996,00.html|accessdate=2007-08-14|postscript=}} ''All About Romance'' has described her as the "rare breed of romance author who has left the genre and yet not alienated her many romance fans." The Plum novels have taken many attributes from Evanovich's own life. Evanovich shares many commonalities with her character Stephanie Plum. Both are from New Jersey, both devour Cheetos, both had owned a hamster, and both have shared "similar embarrassing experiences." The character Grandma Mazur is loosely based on Evanovich's "Grandma Fanny" and "Aunt Lena." Evanovich claims the spirited elderly lady is "who I want to be when I grow up."{{cite web|last=Ward|first=Jean Marie|title=Author Interview: Janet Evanovich: Delivering a Plum Good Read|publisher=Crescent Blues|year=2004|url=http://www.crescentblues.com/7_9issue/int_evanovich.shtml|accessdate=2007-08-14}} Shortly before ''[[One for the Money (novel)|One for the Money]]'' was released, Evanovich sold the movie rights to [[Sony Pictures Motion Picture Group|Columbia TriStar]] for $1 million. [[Lions Gate Entertainment]] released ''[[One for the Money (film)|One for the Money]]'' on January 27, 2012. The film stars [[Katherine Heigl]] as Stephanie Plum, [[Sherri Shepherd]] from ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]'' as Lula, [[Debbie Reynolds]] as Grandma Mazur, [[Jason O'Mara]] as Joe Morelli, and [[Daniel Sunjata]] as Ranger. It was directed by [[Julie Anne Robinson]].{{cite journal | url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/03/23/katherine-heigl-one-for-the-money-january-2012/ | title=Katherine Heigl comedy thriller 'One for the Money' moves to January 2012|last=Rottenberg|first=Josh|date=March 23, 2011|accessdate=2011-12-30}} Her latest Stephanie Plum novel, ''Hardcore Twenty-Four'', was released November 21, 2017 and it reached number one on [[The New York Times Fiction Best Sellers of 2017]] for December 3.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Hardcore-Twenty-Four-Stephanie-Plum-Novel/dp/0399179194/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1488423898&sr=8-1&keywords=hardcore+24|title=Hardcore Twenty-Four|accessdate=March 1, 2017|publisher=Amazon.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/2017/12/03/combined-print-and-e-book-fiction/|title=Combined Print & E-Book Fiction Books - Best Sellers |date=December 3, 2017 |work=The New York Times}} ===Knight & Moon Series=== In 2016 Evanovich released the first book, ''Curious Minds'', in her new Knight & Moon mystery series. Co-authored with Phoef Sutton, the book introduces two new characters, Emerson Knight and Riley Moon. Emerson Knight is a rich, eccentric introvert with little-to-no sense of social etiquette. He is also brilliant and handsome. Riley Moon is a recent Harvard Law and Harvard Business graduate. Her aggressive Texas spitfire attitude helped her land her dream job as a junior analyst at Blane-Grunwald where Emerson is a client. Together this unlikely duo finds themselves thrust into solving the most difficult of mysteries. ''Dangerous Minds'', the second book in the series, was written by Evanovich and released in June 2017. ===Wicked Series=== In 2010 Evanovich published ''Wicked Appetite'', spinning off the character Diesel from the between-the-numbers Plum books. The heroine of ''Wicked Appetite'' is sweet cupcake baker Lizzie Tucker, who, unlike Stephanie Plum, can cook. The "Wicked" series is set in Salem, Massachusetts. In the series, Diesel & Lizzie search for the seven stones of power, each representing a different deadly sin. Lizzie & Diesel are "Unmentionables", humans with additional powers. Their rivals for the stones are Diesel's dark cousin, Gerwulf "Wulf" Grimoire, introduced in ''Plum Spooky'' and his medieval-esque minion Hatchet. Lizzie's animal companions are one-eyed Cat 7143 and Carl the Monkey, from ''Fearless Fourteen'' and ''Plum Spooky''. Her friends include Glo, a "Questionable," and Clara Dazzle, an "Unmentionable" who lost her powers after congress with another "Unmentionable." In ''Wicked Appetite'', the stone sought is that incarnating the sin of gluttony. In 2012 Evanovich published ''Wicked Business'', the second in the series. In ''Wicked Business'', the stone embodies the sin of lust. A new villain is introduced, deranged candy heiress Deirdre Early, or Anarchy. Lizzie, through a selfless act and exchange of body fluids with Wulf, converts the lust stone into the "icky true love stone", implying that in the right circumstances, the stones of sin can be converted into stones of virtue. In 2015 Evanovich teamed up with [[Phoef Sutton]] for the third novel in the series, ''Wicked Charms''. The Stone of Avarice (Greed) is the focus of this installment. ===Fox and O'Hare Series=== In June 2013, Evanovich published the novella "Pros & Cons" and the novel ''The Heist'', the first two works in a new series co-written with [[Lee Goldberg]]. Since then the series has grown to five novels (The Heist, The Chase, The Job, The Scam, and The Pursuit), two novellas (Pros & Cons and The Shell Game) and one online short-story, The Caper. The protagonist is FBI special agent Kate O’Hare who has devoted her career to taking down one of the FBI’s most wanted con men and master thieves, Nick Fox. That is until the FBI pairs Kate with the most unlikely person, Nick Fox, to take down criminals. Together they travel the globe skirting on the edge of what is legal and illegal. Kate’s father, Jake O’Hare, a retired Special Forces operative, often aids in their quest. In June 2016, the fifth novel in the series, The Pursuit, was released. ===Other novels=== Evanovich began a collaborative effort with Charlotte Hughes because she wanted to see some of her other ideas on paper but did not have the time to write them. This resulted in the "Full" series. The "Full" series is set in Beaumont, South Carolina and features Jamie Swift and Maximillian Holt, who meet in the second "Full" book, ''Full Tilt''. The ''Elsie Hawkins'' novels are stand alone romances with a supporting character Elsie Hawkins, who is a gun totin' retiree, with tight grey curls, who "doesn't take sass from no one." Elsie drives a 1957 powder blue Cadillac that never seems to sustain damage. In the Stephanie Plum series, Grandma Mazur and Stephanie drive Uncle Sandor's 1953 powder blue Buick,{{cite book|last=Evanovich|first=Janet|title=Three To Get Deadly|pages=7}} which has similar indestructibility. In 2004, Evanovich launched another series with ''Metro Girl.'' This book debuted at Number 2 on the New York Times Best Seller List. The heroine is Alexandra Barnaby, an auto mechanic. Her love interest is Sam Hooker, a hedonistic NASCAR driver. The "Motor" series is set in the southern U.S. states. Further books in the series include ''Motor Mouth'' and ''Troublemaker 1 & 2'' (graphic novels). Evanovich collaborated with [[Stephen J. Cannell]], noted T.V. writer and producer (''A Team, Rockford Files, Baretta, 21 Jump Street''), on a book entitled ''No Chance'', which was to be the first book in a new series. It was supposed to be released in October 2007. However, in July 2007, the book was canceled.[http://www.mediabistro.com/galleycat/authors/no_chance_of_evanovichcannell_collaboration_63020.asp No Chance of Evanovich/Cannell Collaboration] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070826102131/http://www.mediabistro.com/galleycat/authors/no_chance_of_evanovichcannell_collaboration_63020.asp |date=August 26, 2007 }} Stephen J. Cannell died in 2010 of melanoma. ==Personal life== During the week, Evanovich works eight or more hours per day. On weekends she generally works for an additional four hours each day. She generally creates a brief outline before beginning a new book, with one or two sentences about what will happen in each chapter. Upon the release of a new book, Evanovich regularly goes on book tours. Her book signings attracted thousands of people. Beginning with her third Stephanie Plum book, ''Three to Get Deadly,'' and ending with ''Smokin' Seventeen'', all of the titles have been chosen from fan submissions. Evanovich lives in Florida with her husband, Pete, whom she married in 1964. Pete is of [[Serbs|Serbian]] ancestry. Members of Evanovich's family are employed by her company, Evanovich Inc., including her husband, Pete, son, Peter, and daughter Alexandra. Evanovich's niece (by marriage) is author Stephanie Evanovich. (Stephanie's father is the brother of Janet's husband, Pete.)[http://www.likesbooks.com/blog/?p=10266 A Tale of Two Evanoviches] ==Bibliography== {{Library resources box|by=yes|viaf=54180657 }} === Single romance novels === Originally written under the name Steffie Hall *''Hero at Large'' (1987) *''Thanksgiving'' (1988) *''The Grand Finale'' (1988) *''Wife for Hire'' (1988) - with character Elsie Hawkins *''Foul Play'' (1989) *''Manhunt'' (1988) *''Ivan Takes a Wife'' (1988), then republished as ''Love Overboard'' (2005) *''Back to the Bedroom'' (1989) *''Smitten'' (1990) - with character Elsie Hawkins *''Rocky Road to Romance'' (1991) *''Naughty Neighbor'' (1992) ===Stephanie Plum Series=== # ''[[One for the Money (novel)|One for the Money]]'' (1994) also in '''Three Plums in One''' # ''[[Two for the Dough]]'' (1996) also in '''Three Plums in One''' # ''[[Three to Get Deadly]]'' (1997) also in '''Three Plums in One''' # ''[[Four to Score (novel)|Four to Score]]'' (1998) also in '''More Plums in One''' # ''[[High Five (novel)|High Five]]'' (1999) also in '''More Plums in One''' # ''[[Hot Six]]'' (2000) also in '''More Plums in One''' # ''[[Seven Up (novel)|Seven Up]] ''(2001) # ''[[Hard Eight (novel)|Hard Eight]]'' (2002) # ''[[To the Nines (novel)|To the Nines]]'' (2003) # ''[[Ten Big Ones (novel)|Ten Big Ones]]'' (2004) # ''[[Eleven on Top (novel)|Eleven on Top]]'' (2005) # ''[[Twelve Sharp (novel)|Twelve Sharp]]'' (2006) # ''[[Lean Mean Thirteen]]'' (2007) # ''[[Fearless Fourteen]]'' (2008) # ''[[Finger Lickin' Fifteen]]'' (2009) # ''[[Sizzling Sixteen]]'' (2010) # ''Smokin' Seventeen'' (2011) # ''Explosive Eighteen'' (2011) # ''Notorious Nineteen'' (2012) # ''Takedown Twenty'' (2013) # ''Top Secret Twenty-One'' (2014) # ''Tricky Twenty-Two'' (2015) # ''Turbo Twenty-Three'' (2016) # ''Hardcore Twenty-Four'' (2017) # ''Look Alive Twenty-Five'' (2018)https://www.amazon.com/Look-Alive-Twenty-Five-Stephanie-Novel-ebook/dp/B07B2JQHH8/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1520266986&sr=8-1&keywords=look+alive+twenty-five&dpID=51Z5fAzSJGL&preST=_SY445_QL70_&dpSrc=srch ====Stephanie Plum and Diesel==== :8.5 ''Visions of Sugar Plums'' (2002) also in '''Between the Plums''' :12.5 ''Plum Lovin''' (2007) also in '''Between the Plums''' :13.5 ''Plum Lucky'' (2008) also in '''Between the Plums''' :14.5 ''Plum Spooky'' (2009) === Fox & O'Hare Series === Co-written with Lee Goldberg :0.1 ''[https://www.evanovich.com/the-caper/ The Caper]'' (2018), on line short story :0.2 ''Pros and Cons'' (2013) , ebook only :1 ''The Heist'' (2013) :1.1 ''The Shell Game'' (2015), ebook only :2 ''The Chase'' (2014) :3 ''The Job'' (2014) :4 ''The Scam'' (2015) :5 ''The Pursuit'' (2016) :6 ''The Big Kahuna'' (2019), co-written with [[Peter Evanovich]] ===Lizzy and Diesel Series=== #''[[Wicked Appetite]]'' (2010) #''Wicked Business'' (2012) #''Wicked Charms'' (2015){{cite web| url=https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_ss_c_0_11?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=wicked%20charms&sprefix=wicked+char%2Caps%2C208|title=Wicked Charms|work=Amazon.com|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}, co-written with [[Phoef Sutton]] === Knight and Moon Series === #''Curious Minds'' (August 2016), co-written with [[Phoef Sutton]] #''Dangerous Minds'' (June 2017) === Barnaby and Hooker Series === #''Metro Girl'' (2004) #''Motor Mouth'' (2006) #''Troublemaker'' (graphic novel) #''Troublemaker 2'' (2010; graphic novel) ===Full Series with Max Holt=== Co-written with Charlotte Hughes # ''Full House'' (1989) (re-issued in December 2002) # ''Full Tilt'' (2003) (re-issued in June 2003) # ''Full Speed'' (2003) (re-issued in October 2003) # ''Full Blast'' (2004) (re-issued in January 2004) # ''Full Bloom'' (2005) (re-issued in July 2004) # ''Full Scoop'' (2006) (re-issued in December 2004) ===Co-Authored Romance Novels=== *''Hot Stuff'' (2007), co-written with [[Leanne Banks]] (Cate Madigan) *''Love in a Nutshell'' (2012), co-written with [[Dorien Kelly]] *''The Husband List'' (2013), co-written with [[Dorien Kelly]] ===Anthologies=== * '''The Plot Thickens''' **''The Last Peep'' * '''Three Plums in One''' ** ''One for the Money'' ** ''Two for the Dough'' ** ''Three to Get Deadly'' * '''More Plums in One''' ** ''Four to Score'' ** ''High Five'' ** ''Hot Six'' * '''Between the Plums''' ** ''Visions of Sugar Plums'' ** ''Plum Lovin’'' ** ''Plum Lucky'' ===Non-fiction=== *''How I Write'' (2006) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.evanovich.com/ Janet Evanovich Homepage] *{{worldcat id|id=lccn-n93-124340}} * [http://veronikaasks.wordpress.com/janet-evanovich Interview with Janet Evanovich at Veronika Asks] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Evanovich, Janet}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American graphic novelists]] [[Category:American romantic fiction writers]] [[Category:American mystery writers]] [[Category:20th-century American novelists]] [[Category:People from South River, New Jersey]] [[Category:Rutgers University alumni]] [[Category:Novelists from New Jersey]] [[Category:Writers of books about writing fiction]] [[Category:Dilys Award winners]] [[Category:21st-century American novelists]] [[Category:Women romantic fiction writers]] [[Category:Women mystery writers]] [[Category:American women novelists]] [[Category:20th-century American women writers]] [[Category:21st-century American women writers]] [[Category:Housewives]]

{{Infobox Painting | image_file=Guerin Jeune fille en buste.jpg | image_size=250px | title=Jeune fille en buste | artist=[[Pierre-Narcisse Guérin]] | year = 1794<ref name= "u">{{citeweb|url=http://cartelfr.louvre.fr/cartelfr/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=18876&langue=fr|title=Jeune fille en buste|editor=Louvre}}</ref> | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | width_metric=50 | height_metric=60 | city=[[Paris]], France | museum=[[Musée du Louvre]]<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://cartelfr.louvre.fr/cartelfr/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=18876}|title=Jeune fille en buste}}</ref> | movement =Classicism }} '''''Jeune fille en buste''''' (Portrait of the young girl) is a work by [[Pierre-Narcisse Guérin]] painted in 1794 and exhibited at the [[Musée du Louvre|Louvre]]. One of Guérin's early works, it treats the subject in a frank and direct way. Guérin uses the old "Titus style model". The smooth bottom, the simplicity of the design and the use of the measured color as Regnault left the students towards '''David'''.<ref name= "u"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commonscat|Jeune fille en buste, Guérin}} *[http://www.marynovik.com/backstory/backstory-for-conceit/jeune-fille-en-buste Backstory] *[http://art.rmngp.fr/fr/library/artworks/pierre-narcisse-guerin_jeune-fille-en-buste_huile-sur-toile Imatge] *[http://www.alamy.com/stock-photo-pierre-narcisse-guerin-jeune-fille-en-buste-1794-louvre-museum-paris-57237310.html Botiga]
